title: Impeachment Increasingly Divides Americans by Political Party
content:
WASHINGTON—A polarized nation is dividing even further into its hardened partisan corners , with Republicans firming up opposition to the House impeachment investigation of President Trump and support growing among Democrats for removing him from office , a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds .
Some 53 % of Americans in the survey said they approve of the Democratic-run House impeachment inquiry , with 44 % disapproving . Nearly half—49 % —said that Mr. Trump should be impeached and removed from the White House based on what they have heard so far , with 46 % opposing impeachment and removal .
When the Journal/NBC News poll asked a similar question in early October , support for impeachment and removal lagged behind opposition , 43 % to 49 % .
While many shifts in the course of October are within the polls ’ margins of error , they suggest that Americans are now divided by party over impeachment to the same extensive degree that they are divided over Mr. Trump himself .
Among Democrats , support for removing Mr. Trump from office rose to 88 % , up 13 percentage points from early October and in line with the 92 % who disapprove of the president ’ s job performance .
Among Republicans , opposition to removing Mr. Trump rose to 90 % , up 5 percentage points , and nearly identical to the 91 % who approve of the president ’ s performance in office .
Views of impeachment are only one signal that the election year is unfolding in front of a highly polarized and engaged public . Some 72 % of Americans rate themselves as highly interested in the election—a level normally not seen until the weeks just before Election Day .
Another sign of hardened lines appeared when voters were asked about their 2020 choice . Even before knowing the Democratic nominee , some 34 % said they were certain to vote for Mr. Trump , and 46 % said they were certain to vote against him . Only 17 % said their vote depended on which candidate Democrats select to challenge Mr. Trump—a smaller share than the 27 % who said in 2011 their vote depended on which Republican would face then-President Obama .
Interest in the election is equal among Democrats and Republicans and is high enough to suggest that turnout will break records next year , adding new uncertainties to the outcome , pollsters said . Bill McInturff , a Republican who conducted the survey with Democrat Jeff Horwitt , called it “ a supercharged electorate ’ ’ and said : “ When you get an electorate that no one has ever seen , it gets harder to make predictions . ”
Mr. Horwitt said the survey finds little sign of political pressure from the Republican base on the GOP senators to remove Mr. Trump from office , should the House vote to impeach . But the poll also points to “ a much more challenging road ahead come next November with judges at the ballot box , ’ ’ he said .
In tests against two leading Democratic primary candidates , Mr. Trump trailed former Vice President Joe Biden by 9 percentage points , 41 % to 50 % , and trailed Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts by 8 points , 42 % to 50 % .
In other challenges for Mr. Trump , half of those in the survey said they had no confidence that he has the right goals and policies , with an additional 14 % saying they were “ only somewhat confident. ’ ’ That compared with 35 % who had high levels of confidence in Mr. Trump .
A majority gave Mr. Trump low marks for serving as commander in chief . A 41 % plurality said Mr. Trump ’ s decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria was the wrong decision , while 29 % said it was the right call . At the same time , a plurality said the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi in a U.S. military operation last week would make the U.S. safer .
The survey found that Mr. Trump does carry strengths into the next election beyond a unified party . Some 52 % of adults said they approved of his handling of the economy , a larger share than the 45 % who approved of his job performance overall .
To Mr. McInturff , the survey drew a picture of stability in attitudes toward the president . He pointed out that Mr. Trump ’ s approval rating has moved within a narrow , four-point range in 17 of the past 18 Journal/NBC News surveys dating to June of last year , with between 43 % and 46 % of Americans approving of his job performance .
“ Is this impeachment hearing impacting Donald Trump ’ s political standing ? The answer to that to date—and I want to answer that emphatically…is no , it ’ s not , ’ ’ Mr. McInturff said . “ These are the exact same numbers we ’ ve been seeing for a year and a half . ’ ’
Independents take a negative view of how Mr. Trump is handling his job , with 38 % approving and 54 % disapproving . Views of impeachment are more tempered among independents , however , with 43 % saying he should be removed from office and 46 % opposing removal .

One group that moved more firmly behind the president is Republicans who say they support the GOP itself more than they support Mr. Trump , often called “ establishment Republicans. ” In surveys , this group often shows lackluster support for some of Mr. Trump ’ s policies and distaste for some of his personal qualities . In the new poll , some 11 % of these Republicans said Congress should remove the president from office , down from 21 % in early October .
The survey also tracked preferences among voters who said they would participate in a Democratic primary or caucus . Mr. Biden led the field , with 27 % support , followed by Ms. Warren , at 23 % , and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont at 19 % .
In single digits were Pete Buttigieg , with 6 % support ; Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota , at 5 % , and Sen. Kamala Harris of California at 4 % . Other contenders had less than 4 % support .
The results marked a decline in support for Mr. Biden of 4 percentage points from September , and a drop of 2 points for Ms. Warren . Support for Mr. Sanders rose by 5 points from September .
Of the three leading candidates , Mr. Sanders ’ s support appeared to be the most firm . Some 57 % who named him as their top choice for nominee said their support was definite , compared with 50 % of Biden voters and 32 % who favored Ms. Warren .
Ms. Warren led the field , however , when voters were asked their second choice for nominee , suggesting that she would have the most to gain if support for her rivals diminished .
The Journal/NBC News survey interviewed 900 adults from Oct. 27-30 . The margin of error was plus or minus 3.27 percentage points for the full sample .
